rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you. See [[WP:FIXNF]] and [[WP:10CR]]
rev.diff:
Line 73: Line 73:
===Invasion of the Soviet Union===
===Invasion of the Soviet Union===
The German military had traditonally considered Communism in the Soviet Union to be a Jewish plot before the Third Reich. In 1918, Karl von Bothmer, the German Army's plenipotenitary in Moscow called the Bolsheviks "a gang of Jews" and expressed the desire "to see a few hundred of these louts hanging on the Kremlin wall".<ref>FÃ¶rster, JÃ¼rgen. "The German Military's Image of Russia", pp. 117-129 from ''Russia War, Peace and Diplomacy'' edited by Ljubica and Mark Erickson, London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson, 2004, 2005, p. 118.</ref> Evaluations of the Red Army by the visting ''Reichswehr'' officers during the period of German-Soviet co-operation in the 1920s often show antisemitism with comments about the "Jewish slyness" of General Lev Snitman or the "Jewish blood" of General Leonid Vajner being very typical.<ref>FÃ¶rster, JÃ¼rgen "The German Military's Image of Russia", pp. 117-129 from ''Russia War, Peace and Diplomacy'' edited by Ljubica and Mark Erickson, London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson, 2004, 2005, p. 118.</ref> In 1932, Ewald Banse, a leading German professor and a member of the National Association for the Military Sciences (a group secretly financed by the ''Reichswehr'') wrote in a pamphlet calling for "intellectual world domination" by Germany wrote that the Soviet leadership was mostly Jewish who dominated an apathetic and mindless Russian masses.<ref>FÃ¶rster, JÃ¼rgen. "The German Military's Image of Russia", pp. 117-129 from ''Russia War, Peace and Diplomacy'' edited by Ljubica and Mark Erickson, London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson, 2004, 2005, p. 119.</ref>
The German military had traditonally considered Communism in the Soviet Union to be a Jewish plot before the Third Reich. In 1918, Karl von Bothmer, the German Army's plenipotenitary in Moscow called the Bolsheviks "a gang of Jews" and expressed the desire "to see a few hundred of these louts hanging on the Kremlin wall".<ref>FÃ¶rster, JÃ¼rgen. "The German Military's Image of Russia", pp. 117-129 from ''Russia War, Peace and Diplomacy'' edited by Ljubica and Mark Erickson, London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson, 2004, 2005, p. 118.</ref> Evaluations of the Red Army by the visting ''Reichswehr'' officers during the period of German-Soviet co-operation in the 1920s often show antisemitism with comments about the "Jewish slyness" of General Lev Snitman or the "Jewish blood" of General Leonid Vajner being very typical.<ref>FÃ¶rster, JÃ¼rgen "The German Military's Image of Russia", pp. 117-129 from ''Russia War, Peace and Diplomacy'' edited by Ljubica and Mark Erickson, London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson, 2004, 2005, p. 118.</ref> In 1932, Ewald Banse, a leading German professor and a member of the National Association for the Military Sciences (a group secretly financed by the ''Reichswehr'') wrote in a pamphlet calling for "intellectual world domination" by Germany wrote that the Soviet leadership was mostly Jewish who dominated an apathetic and mindless Russian masses.<ref>FÃ¶rster, JÃ¼rgen. "The German Military's Image of Russia", pp. 117-129 from ''Russia War, Peace and Diplomacy'' edited by Ljubica and Mark Erickson, London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson, 2004, 2005, p. 119.</ref>

[[Image:Nazi Lithuanian poster.JPG|thumb|left|1941 [[Nazi propaganda]] poster in the [[Lithuanian language]], equating [[Stalinism]] with the Jews. The text reads "The Jew is our enemy forever".]]
+
In 1935, Colonel [[Carl-Heinrich von StÃ¼lpnagel]] in a report about the military capacity of the Red Army wrote that the commissars were "mostly of the Jewish race".<ref>FÃ¶rster, JÃ¼rgen. "The German Military's Image of Russia", pp. 117-129 from ''Russia War, Peace and Diplomacy'' edited by Ljubica and Mark Erickson, London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson, 2004, 2005, p. 121.</ref>
